title-group.article-title: Some New Variance Bounds for Asset Prices

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2005 The Ohio State University Press

abstract.p: When equity prices are determined as the discounted sum of current and expected future dividends, Shiller (1981) and LeRoy and Porter (1981) derived a relationship between the variance of the price of equities, p<sub>t</sub>, and the variance of the ex post realized discounted sum of current and future dividends: <tex-math>$p_{t}^*: Var(p_{t}^*) \geq Var(p_t)$</tex-math>. The literature has long since recognized that this variance bound is valid only when dividends follow a stationary process. Others, notably West (1988), derive variance bounds that apply when dividends are nonstationary. West shows that the variance in innovations in p<sub>t</sub> must be less than the variance of innovations in a forecast of the discounted sum of current and future dividends constructed by the econometrician, <tex-math>$\hat{p}_t$</tex-math>. Here we derive a new variance bound when dividends are stationary or have a unit root, that sheds light on the discussion in the 1980s of the Shiller variance bound: <tex-math>$Var(p_{t} - p_{t-1}) \geq Var(p_{t}^* - p_{t-1}^*)$</tex-math>! We also derive a variance bound related to the West bound: <tex-math>$Var(\hat{p}_{t} - \hat{p}_{t-1}) \geq Var(p_{t} - p_{t-1})$</tex-math>.
